result.execSummary:
The defendant Brian Wilke was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Theft-Business Setting <=$2500, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(b).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
Submit a DNA sample by 6-10-2022 and pay the surcharge by 12-7-2022. Failure to pay will result in a civil judgment/tax intercept.
Pay all costs, fees and surcharges by 12/7/2022. Failure to pay will result in a civil judgment/tax intercept.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Brian Wilke

records.addlTxt:
AS TO COUNT 1:  Defendant changes plea(s) to GUILTY. Defendant examined as to plea, advised of Constitutional Rights and the maximum penalties. Defendant further advised that if not a US citizen, deportation is possible. Court found that the defendant knowingly, voluntarily and intelligently waived rights.  Plea Questionnaire/Waiver of Rights form, Addendum, and Elements/Jury Instructions received and filed. Parties stipulate to the Criminal Complaint as a factual basis to sustain defendant's plea(s).  Court found defendant GUILTY and ordered a Judgment of Conviction be entered on the record.  
*
Sentencing proceeded.  Statements by the State, defense and defendant.   Court finds victim notification has been complied with.

Court ordered the defendant to pay a fine of $500.00.

- Submit a DNA sample by 6/10/22 and pay the surcharge by 12/07/22.  Failure to pay will result in a civil judgment/tax intercept

- Pay ALL costs, fees and surcharges BY 12/07/22. Failure to pay will result in a civil judgment/tax intercept.
- Defendant advised of his right to appeal.

Defendant Brian Wilke in court with attorney Michael G. Levine.  
Nicolas J Heitman appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  
Deputy Court Clerk: rmm.  
Defendant is advised this case is assigned to Judge Davila, Branch 1. Court reviewed the complaint and found probable cause.  Defendant advised of right to counsel and complaint given to defendant's attorney.  Defendant pled not guilty.
Plea Questionnaire Waiver of Rights and Addendum, filed.  rmm
